div.p: 1. V. Sunday— Wrote to Charles— Heard Mr Fowler Jeremiah
Mr Hawley— read prayers for Circumcision day

list.item: Sermon— Philippians diarized this Eve Rain— Gale

div.p: 2. VI.30. Monday. Fahrenheit 10.— D. J. Pearce, Ballou, Sprague, Borden N, Jackson, Hazeltine, Love, Slade, Jaynes, L. Williams, Hawley, Fendall; Mrs Stewart—sundry Cards— Severe cold
Elizabeth De Wint— Cards— Letter to R. Clark.
3. VI:45. Tuesday— Fahrenheit 12— Children to School.

At the House Dr Howe and the blind— Petitions— Resolution relating to Pensions— Garland’s Resolution— Harlan’s Amendment Vanderpoel’s— Balie Peyton’s— Garland’s 3. Resolutions adopted 199 ayes— Wise’s Resolution D. J. Pearce’s amendment— Pickens, Dunlap— Peyton— Robertson—adjourned at 4— Eliz. de Wint. Evening party at Genl. Macomb’s— The young Ladies went—
Pettrich here this morning— Letter to P. Gay.
4. VI:30. Wednesday.

At the House— Chilton Allan’s Resolution about the distribution of the proceeds of public Lands— Davis— Claiborne, Ashley Vinton—debate arrested— Wise’s Resolution— Pickens, Peyton, Dunlap— Robertson— Adjournment— Evening Ball at Mr Forsyth’s— Elizabeth Adams went.
5. VI. Thursday

Committee of Manufactures— Memorial and Petition— General discussion— House. C. Allan’s Resolution— Harrison of Missouri— Parker, Briggs, Motion to lay on the table rejected 99 to 95— Belknap— Messenger who brought the Ohio votes— Corwin for my Reports on Manufactures. B. Payton, for my Report on the Bank— Wise’s Resolution— Robertson concluded— Hannegan— Hamer—adjournment— Elizabeth De Wint dined with us—despatched many documents.
6. VI:30. Friday.

House— Private Business— Bill to admit Michigan, reported by Thomas— Boon reports a Bill to restrict sales of public Lands— Gillet’s motion to print old Documents—rejected— Bill to pay Letcher and Moore passed— Elizabeth C. Adams passed the day at Judge Cranch’s.
7. VI:30. Saturday

Fahrenheit 30—blustering cold. At the House Evariste Maury— Land Claims— Private business— Michigan Bill— Thomas moves special order for next Tuesday—rejected— J. Bell shewed me his Bill to secure the Freedom of Elections— F. O. J. Smith book back his bill to establish a Home Department— A. Mann came and talked with me— Jarvis gave notice of a meeting of the Comee. on Paintings next Monday at 10— Private Bill rejected— Rode home— Whist.
8. VI:30. Sunday.

Church with Elizabeth C. Adams and Elizabeth De Wint— Heard Mr Fowler Exodus 20.8. Mary dined at Mr Frye’s— Afternoon at St. John’s— Mr Hawley. 1. Sunday after Epiphany— Revelation 20.11— Mrs. W. S. Smith and Elizabeth De Wint— Ladies spent the Eve at Mr Frye’s— I wrote a Petition for Mrs Tudor.
9. VI. Monday

Call on Mrs Tudor, who signed the Petition— Met at 10. O’Clock the joint Committee on the paintings—Preston, Wall, Jarvis M’Keon and H. Johnson— Absent S. Wright and B. C. Howard— Adjourned to Saturday at 10. House— Petitions. Mrs D. Tudor Call on P.U.S—adopted. referred to Comee. on foreign relations— Enquiry of C. C. Cambreleng concerning petition of British authors— Abolition Petitions. presented 3— Different decisions— Question of receiving decided and renewed. Underwood, Bynum— I received 6 more abolition Petitions—

10. V. Tuesday. Cold mitigated— House— Davis of Indiana moves suspension of the rules for his sweeping anti-abolition resolutions. 102 to 78. Not two thirds— Unfinished business— Wise’s Resolution Pearces substitute— Hamer finished his speech begun last Thursday
11. IV:30. Wednesday

House— Cambreleng from Comee. of Ways and means presents an Anti Tariff Bill and Report—smuggled to a second reading— Bill and Report read. Lawrence, warm debate— Motions to take up the orders of the day rejected. Corwin moves adjournment— Balie Peyton— Henry— Company to dine— Joseph Blunt
12. IV.15. Thursday— Nearly sleepless Night Cramps

dismal day— Met Comee. of Manufactures—Adams, Denny, Granger, Lee, Fowler, Whittlesey— Talk of Tariff, and Cambreleng’s Bill— No conclusion— House— Corwin’s Speech— Muhlenberg moves to lay the Bill on the Table rejected— Referred to Comee of the whole on the Union—119 to 94. Call of the House— Hannegan’s notice of substitute for second Section— Ride to the Capitol and home.— Bird Nathaniel’s Petition Elizabeth went to the Theatre
13. VII. Friday

Restorative Night’s rest— Persico—to get Mr Buchanan to introduce him to Mr Van Buren. House. Tariff Bill referred to Comee. of the whole on the Union, and made special order for next Thursday—10000 Copies of report and Bill to be printed— Private Bills Comee. of the whole. M’Kennon and Ward successively in the Chair— A few private Bills passed—many laid aside—adjourned at 4. I rode home with the Ladies— Snow— John Connell.— Snow
14. VI:15. Saturday—

Met the joint Comee. on the Paintings, at 10. After a call upon Mrs Tudor—present, Preston, Wall, Wright—Jarvis, Howard, M’Keon, absent Johnson of Louisiana— Agreed to reserve one pannel for Allston— Jarvis to write to him— Vanderlyn’s sketch to be viewed, and Inman informed that the Comee will expect a sketch from him
House— Howard’s proposal to commence at the South for Petitions next Monday— 88 to 46—not 2/3. Private business—rode to and from the Capitol— W. Jagger
15. VI. Sunday.— Heard A. W. Bishop. Morn and P.M. Isaiah 9.6 Job 37:22. F. Hassler this Eve— Letter to Greene and Osborne
16. VI. Monday

Mr Bird came and signed his Petition. Dr. Huntt was here— Louisa unwell— At the House— Howard moves by suspension of the rules to call for Petitions in inverted order—carried by 2/3 Petition from Ohio Colonization Society, presented by Jones—laid on table— Remonstrance of the grand-jury—presented by the Speaker—read laid on table— Motions to print— Abolition Petitions—objections—laid on the table—when the turn comes to Massachusetts for Petitions, Parks moves to adjourn carried Evening at whist.
17. VI.30. Tuesday.

Pettrich brought several further engravings— Cornelius—Overbeck prime Painters— At the House— Underwood attempted to introduce anti-expunging Resolutions but failed— F. Thomas attempted to suspend all the rules to take up the Michigan admission Bill—failed. Chilton Allan’s Land distribution Bill—failed. Wise’s Resolution— Speeches of M’Keon and Jenifer— Vanderpoel moves Previous question carried—vote 121 to 52— Resolution carried. 165: 9. Bell gave notice again of his Bill— Todd here this Evening— Mary and Elizabeth went to the concert with Mr and Mrs Lay.
18. VI:30 Wednesday

Hawes moved a Resolution for laying on the table all abolition petitions; which was carried by the previous question. 129. 69— Engrossed Bills read and passed— Mileage Bill, driven to the third reading by Previous question— Bill for the admission of Michigan into the Union— Commitment to the Committee of the whole on the Union 86. 110— Evening party at Mr Butler’s Elizabeth went with Mr and Mrs Lay— T. J. Frye here— Cards.
19. VI:30. Thursday—

Meeting of Comee. of Manufactures, Adams, Denny, Lee, M Comas, Webster, Whittlesey Absent, Bynum, Granger Fowler— I asked Instructions of the Comee. whether to take any notice of the Report and Bill of the Comee. of Ways and Means— After some conversation I was instructed to prepare and submit to the Comee a Report and if I pleased, a Bill— In the House, Owens of Georgia, moved suspension of the Rules to present Resolutions of the Legislature of Georgia upon the deposit Bill, but failed— Harlan of Kentuckey moved a Resolution of instructing the Post office Comee to ensure the building rented of B. O. Tayloe— Underwood offered a Resolution that the Serjeant at arms should enquire and ascertain the Mileage claimed by members and also by Senators—raised a sputter— Hardin shewed his mortification— Orders of the day called— Act for the admission of Michigan— Long Speech of Thomas— Dull Speech of Hardin in answer to Thomas Vanderpoel takes the floor— adjourn Took Lay home— Revd Mr Killikelly— Cards
20. VI:15. Friday—

Letter to Rowland Johnson Philadelphia. House— Underwood’s motion to enquire into the claims of Mileage by Members and Senators— Fluttering of the Pigeons— Claiborne of Mississippi Yell of Arkansas orders of the day. Sundry private Bills— Remission of duty upon Salt destroyed by fire— Bill rejected— Saw B. F Hallett, this day and yesterday— Evening Cards.— B. F. Hallett was in the House C A. Grammer and Mr Engel, brought me the Senate Bill concerning the Franklin Insurance Company. J. M. H. Beale shewed me two Bills from the Committee on Revolutionary Pensions, one of which he presented, and He named? the other for an additional Section which I drew up and propose to offer as an amendment. Mr Henry of N.C called me out to enquire concerning the construction of the 8th. Article of the Treaty of 1819. with Spain.
21. VI:30 Saturday

At the House— Underwood’s Resolution that the Sergeant at arms should enquire into the mileage, claimed by members of the House and Senate raised a squally debate—Hardin—Claiborne of Mississippi—Yell of Arkansas—they claim mileage by the river route— Claiborne and Yell, propose amendments— I proposed that the Clerk, should make the enquiry instead of the Sergeant at arms accepted by Underwood— Orders of the day— Bill for relief ofremission of duties upon Salt, destroyed by fire—long debate—Cushing—Phillips—Cambreleng, D. J. Pearce G. Lee—case nearly the same with rejected Bill of yesterday— I made a short undigested, desultory Speech— Previous question immediately called and carried Bill passed to 3d. reading by yeas and nays 87 to 65—H. Johnson—A Lawrence—Mercer Briggs— Beale reported his Bill from the Comee. of Revolutionary Pensions— I presented my amendatory Section to be printed with the Bill. Snow Storm all day— Evening whist
22. VI:30. Sunday— Snow-storm and gale

At St. Johns Church— Mr Killikelly read prayers. 3d. Sunday after Epiphany— Mr Stemm of Harrisburg preached Acts 17–30—without Notes— Admirable— Beginning report for the Comee of Manufactures— Deep concern and oppressive occupation
23. VI:30— Monday.

At the House— Petitions— The Speaker called upon Cushing. I called for the unfinished business upon the petition from Dover of the 9th: instt: suspended by Bynum’s unfinished Speech—the Speaker said the house had disposed of that by the Resolution of last Wednesday to lay on the table all papers relating to Slavery— I appealed from this decision which was confirmed by yeas and nays.— The other members from Massachusetts then presented their petitions, after which I presented the Petition of Nathaniel Bird, for arrears of Pension, which with some resistance from Wardwell chairman of the Committee of Revolutionary Pensions, was referred to the Committee of the whole, to whom the Bill reported on Saturday by Beal with my proposed amendment is referred. I then presented in succession forty petitions for the abolition of Slavery and the Slave trade in the District of Columbia—all laid on the table that from Dover and that from Dorchester which I refused to present again to the House— Special debate upon the Petition ofSwackhamer, and 53 Ministers and Members of the Lutheran Church— Speaker decided it came within the provisions of the Table Resolution— I appealed from the Speaker’s decision which was confirmed by the House by yeas and nays 155 to 3— Many other abolition petitions were presented— The States were called through— adjourned at 4. The young Ladies spent the eve at Mrs Smith’s.
24. VI:30 Tuesday

Mr Hill brought Vol’s 2 and 3. of the Gallery of American Portraits and insisted on my taking them— Mr French and Mr Cabot were here as visitors— At the House the first hour was consumed in receiving Reports of Committees— Patton reported from the Library Committee a Resolution to purchase Mr Madison’s manuscripts for 30000 dollars— I proposed it should be changed into a Bill—referred to the Committee of the whole on the Union— Beale got the Committee of the whole discharged from his Bill reported on Saturday last, and had it referred to the Committee of the whole on the Union. The Michigan admission Bill was the order of the day— Vanderpoel, Storer, and Toucey made Speeches— Mann of New-York moved the previous Question, but the House adjourned— T. J. Frye was here this Evening— Then Revd. Mr Burton— Mary and Elizabeth spent the Evening at Mr W. S. Smith’s—

div.p: 25. VI:30. Wednesday

At the houseHerod of Indiana appeared and took his Seat, in the place of George L. Kinnard, who lost his life on his way to Washington in November last, by the bursting of the pipe of a Steam-boat boiler on the Ohio river— Lane of Indiana introduced him to me— Underwood’s Resolution of enquiry into the mileage claimed by members, was debated with essence of wormwood. Claiborne of Mississippi and Yell of Arkansas had shewn their mortification and spite by moving spiteful and silly amendments— Bell relieved them and the house by moving to lay the whole subject on the table, which was carried— The States were called for Resolutions and Bell at last moved for leave to introduce his Bill to secure the freedom of elections. The Bill was read and Bell made part of his Speech, till the expiration of the first hour, when Vanderpoel called for the orders of the day,—The Michigan admission Bill— Mann had yesterday moved the previous Question, and Jenifer a call of the House which he now withdrew— The previous question was carried and the Bill passed to a third reading 148 to 58— Read a 3d time and passed— Squabble between Jenifer—Thomas, Howard and Pearce, about the late party convulsions in Maryland— Cushman moves the previous question—carried— Bill passed 142 to 43— Adjourned— I congratulated Norvell the Senator from Michigan, but he professed not to be satisfied— Le Row, reporter for the Emancipator, asked me, if the Report of the debate of last Monday on the abolition Petitions, in the Intelligencer was not correct— I found it full of gross errors, and complained of it to Seaton—and told him I would send him a minute of the errors and omissions to-morrow morning— I was this Evening and till 1. in the morning occupied in revising the report and pointing out its errors— Mary and Elizabeth went this Evening with W. S. Smith, Elizabeth de Wint and Thomas J. Frye to the Theatre, and saw Celeste for the last time—
26. VI:45. Thursday

Meeting of the Committee of Manufactures at 11. Present Adams, Denny, Granger, G. Lee, Bynum, M’Comas Webster and Whittlesey— I was instructed to report against the passage of the Bill from the Senate authorising the importation of an Iron Steam-boat in parts, duty free— Read the Letters from A. T. Judson and F. G. Comstock, and submitted the Treatise on the culture of Silk, and the Silk culturist, 22 numbers, and was instructed to answer Mr Comstock’s Letter— Petition from a Pole
for a reward for the discovery of a method of extracting the impurities from salt— Chairman instructed to ask to be discharged from the further consideration of the Petition and that it be laid on the Table— I made accordingly the Reports to the House—the iron Steamboat Bill was referred to the Committee of the whole, made the order of the day for to-morrow, and to be printed— Bell continued his Speech upon his motion for leave to introduce a Bill to secure the Freedom of Elections till he touched Cambreleng who then called for the orders of the day— Debate upon the Bill from a joint Committee for establishing a uniform rule for computing the mileage of members— Mawkish debate upon it by sundry members— Yell of Arkansas yelled over again his Speech against Underwood’s Resolution, and moved again the same amendments; to reduce the daily pay of members to 6. dollars and to remove the Seat of Government to the Ohio to Mississippi— Motion to lay the Bill on the table—rejected— Previous question rejected. To recommit the Bill—to adjourn— Message from P.U.S. with Documents concerning Mexico and Texas— Howard moves its reference to Comee of foreign Affairs— Linn Boyd moves instructions to report a Resolution—recognizing the Independence of Texas— House adjourn— Call at National Intelligencer Office—left with Gales my Letter, correcting the errors of the report of the abolition petition debate— Elizabeth went to an Evening party at Mrs Hill’s— Santa Anna went off this morning for Norfolk.
27. VI:30. Friday

Mr Sherburne was here this morning, and recommended to my attention, the claim of the legal representatives of John Paul Jones, now before Congress—compensation for the prizes sent into Norway by Landais in 1779. and there seized and delivered up by the Danish Government to the British Consul at Bergen— Long conversation with Mr Sherburne about Jones, Landais and my own life— At the House after the reading of the Journal, Isaac Crary presented himself as the Representative from the People of the State of Michigan.
Robertson of Virginia, objected to his being sworn, and made an argument, which produced a debate of an hour and a half—finally settled by the Previous Question— Jarvis in a moment of petulance, speaking of Bell’s projected Bill, to secure the Freedom of Elections said he must know that no Legislation could follow from it, and that he was urging it only for the gratification of personal feeling— Bell started up and said it was false from beginning to end— The Speaker furiously called Bell to order, and Bell told him it was the duty of the Speaker to have called Jarvis to order— Polk, somewhat abashed, fumbled for his Parliamentary Manual, and read the passage that disorderly words are not to be noticed till the member has finished his speech, as if that was the rule for the Speaker in keeping order— He said too that he had not been particularly attending to what Jarvis was saying, or he should have called him to order, if he had thought he was making personal reflections— From this time till past 5. O’Clock was a snarling debate to settle whether Bell should retract or Jarvis should explain first— The Peace makers or and the war makers intermeddled with the dispute, and in the space of four hours brought the parties to retract and explain, as should have been done in a space of five minutes— I took no part in the contest, and did not open my lips— Yet I was so much exhausted with fatigue that I could not finish in the Evening, a Letter in answer to John G. Whittier which I had begun in the House
28. VI:45 Saturday

Finished the Letter to Whittier this morning; and at the House wrote lines in the Album of Elizabeth Beaumont, daughter of Andrew Beaumont a member of the House of Representatives from Pennsylvania— My Letter to the Editors of the National Intelligencer, correcting the Report in their Paper of Wednesday, of the debate on the abolition Petitions last Monday, was not in the paper this Morning— I enquired of Seaton this morning why? as they had sent me the proof print of it yesterday— He gave no satisfactory reason—and I asked him to restore in the paper of Monday the first paragraph of my
Letter which they had omitted from the proof they sent me yesterday. Le Row a Reporter for the Emancipator had been to me several times for my correction of the Report in the Intelligencer— I desired him to write to the Editors of the Emancipator, not to publish the Report until they shall get my corrective Letter. Vanderpoel, by a suspension of the Rules offered and carried a Resolution that the hour of meeting of the House shall henceforth be eleven O’Clock A.M. When the private business came up, Jarvis’s motion to reconsider the rejection of the Bill for the relief ofwas debated about two hours; and I was very unwillingly drawn into it— The motion was finally laid upon the table— The bill for the relief of Ebenezer Breed was then debated over again at the third reading till there came a previous question and a fruitless effort for a call of the House two or three votes without a quorum; and at last the Bill passed by yeas and nays—Besides its being Saturday—private Bill day, when half the time, there is never a quorum, there was in the Senate the attraction of a snarling debate between Benton and Walker of Mississippi, Robertson told Patton that the President had written a Letter to Wise’s Committee of investigation, calling upon them to summon before them Clay, Calhoun and Preston, to prove their charges against him or pass for calumniators— We made this Evening a party at whist.
29. Sunday. VII.

Heard this morning at the Presbyterian Church, Mr Fowler from Isaiah 53.1. “Who hath believed our report; and unto whom is the arm of the Lord revealed?[”] A solemn and impressive discourse deeply and affectionately deploring the religious coldness and apathy of the times— He said that for the last two years there had not been the addition of one member to that Church, and gave notice that the Communion would be administered next Sunday— Thomas J. Frye dined with us— After dinner I took with me my Grandchild Mary Louisa, and went to St. John’s Church, where Mr
Hawley read the Evening service for the 4th. Sunday after the Epiphany and preached from Isaiah 52.7. “How beautiful upon the mountains are the feet of him that bringeth good tidings, that publisheth peace; that bringeth good tidings of good, that publisheth salvation; that saith unto Zion, thy God reigneth.”— Oh! what a text for a Christian preacher!— This verse is one of the most stirring of the Prophet Isaiah whose Book it is impossible for a believer in the Christian Religion to read without feelings of irrepressible enthusiasm—the Discourse was cool— Mr Calvert of Baltimore spent part of the Evening here
30. VI.30. Monday

The House met at eleven O’Clock— I presented 21. Petitions praying for the abolition of Slavery and the Slave trade in the District of Columbia, after first asking permission to address the House on the right of the Petitioners to have their Petitions read—which was refused by yeas and nays—I moved that every successive petition should be read— The Speaker in every case decided it should not be read—because he said they all came within the order of the 18th. I appealed from every decision, and a motion was immediately made, by Cushman of New-Hampshire to lay the appeal on the table, not debateable, and always carried— I presented the memorial of the Young Men’s Anti-Slavery Society of the City and County of Philadelphia, remonstrating against the recognition of Texas— The Speaker decided that this Memorial came within the order of the House and should go with out reading on the table— From this decision I appealed, and asked for the yeas and nays— Phillips rose and said if the Memorial was not read he should ask to be excused from voting on the question The Speaker against his own decision allowed the memorial to be read, and Mercer immediately insisted that the Memorial was not within the order of the House— But a motion was made to lay the Memorial and the whole subject on the table which was carried.— There were two Petitions presented one by Harlan, and
Harlan; and the other by John Calhoun, from Citizens of Kentucky praying pecuniary aid to the Colonization Society— The first was referred without question taken to the Committee of Foreign Affairs. When the question was made by me whether it did not come within the order of the House of the 18th. C. Pinckney immediately moved to lay the Petition on the table, which was rejected. Huntsman of Tennessee said he had been many years one of the Vice President’s of the Colonization Society, and had never heard or understood that it had any reference to Slavery— Davis of Indiana moved to lay it on the table, which was done— The States were called through for Petitions— White of Florida offered two Resolutions— The first was to transfer upwards of 90 Land claim cases from the Judge of the Eastern District Court of Florida’s Court, to that of the Middle District. I opposed this, and the further consideration of it was postponed— I moved the reconsideration of the vote by which Calhoon’s Kentucky Petition for funds in aid of the Colonization Society— And after some resistance the Speaker allowed the entry of the motion for reconsideration, and postponed it till next Monday— Adjourned between 4 and 5— In the Evening with my wife, Elizabeth C. Adams Mary and her two children I went to the New Theatre; and saw Paudeen O’Rafferty or the Irishman’s fortune— Born to good luck and the Irish Tutor—in both of which Power played parts of an humorous Irishman, for which he is famed— Both farces, rather dull but Power has much of the comic Irish humour— There was a third Piece, the Illustrious Stranger, which we did not stay to see. The House was full— Many Members of Congress there— Mr Turnbull came nearly home with me—till we met the carriage returning for me, from taking home the Ladies and Children—
31. VII. Tuesday

J. C. Alford from Georgia, a member in the place of Townes took his seat— The Journal of the proceedings of yesterday contained misrepresentations of the proceedings of which I complained without obtaining any amendment; I moved however a reconsideration of
the reference to the Committee of foreign affairs of one of the Petitions from Kentuckey in behalf of the Colonization Society, after some hesitation of the Speaker, and it was postponed till next Monday— Thomas from the Committee on the judiciary, was authorised to send for persons and papers to investigate the charges against judge Buckner Thruston, by W. L. Brent, and Richard S. Coxe— Connor from the Post Office Committee reported a Bill for erecting a new Post-Office building— Bell concluded his Speech on his motion for live to bring in a Bill to secure the freedom of elections.— He noticed a furious Article in the Globe of this morning, against him and me; and said that so far as it related to him, it was an infamous calumny. When Bell concluded, Graves of Kentuckey obtained the floor but Cambreleng called for the orders of the day— The House went into Committee of the whole on the Union, and took up the Indian Appropriation Bill— Craig of Virginia in the Chair The Bill differs from the corresponding Bills of late years by comprizing multitudes of spefic items in a few general charges— It passed through the Committee however with several amendments proposed by Cambreleng, without opposition or debate— The Bill was reported to the House and adjourned on motion of Mr Cushing, who said he had something on the Indian Appropriation Bill, with relation to our Indian relations— Evening occupied till very late in writing to the Petitioners for abolition of Slavery in the District of Columbia, from the 12th. Congressional District of Massachusetts.
Wednesday 1. February 1837.

Day— Rise seldom before 6. Often not before seven— Cold chamber and often no fire— Hear the children read— Breakfast between 9 and 10— Receive the Mail— Newspapers and Letters till compelled to go to the House—walk and ride— Home about 5. dined— Eve, writing by Lamp-Light, or at Cards— Failing eyes and hands.
